facts.text: Appellant filed shipping bill in triplicate on 26 July 1966 before Joint Chief Controller of Imports and Exports, Panaji, Goa for 10,160 metric tonnes of iron ore.
Export licence granted to appellant on 28 July 1966.
On 30 July 1966, agents of S.S. Ardenode applied to Assistant Collector of Customs, Marmagao for entry outwards to load iron ore; granted same day.
On 1 August 1966, appellant presented shipping bills dated 26 July 1966 to Customs authorities under section 50 of Customs Act 1962, with declaration as to truth of contents.
On 1 August 1966, Customs authorities endorsed shipping bill: rotation No. 730, 'Let export after examination if necessary', E.F.No. 3/1/8/1966.
On 2 August 1966, Customs authorities made further endorsements on shipping bill: 'PI as usual', 'checked des Inspected the lot-2-barges-checli des', 'Pd in full'.
On 2 August 1966, Ministry of Commerce issued notification under section 4-A of Indian Tariff Act 1934 amending second schedule, introducing item 28 'lumpy iron ore' at Rs. 10 per tonne export duty.
S.S. Ardenode arrived at Marmagao at 23.20 hours on 2 August 1966.
Vessel arrived at Marmagao Inner Harbour on 3 August 1966 at 07.50 hours; commenced loading cargo on 3 August 1966.
9804.40 metric tonnes of iron ore shipped on S.S. Ardenode on 3 August 1966.
On 28 January 1967, Customs authorities issued notice to appellant under section 28 of Customs Act notifying liability for export duty Rs. 98044 at Rs. 10 per metric tonne.
On 19 April 1967, Customs authorities held appellant liable for duty, deeming shipping bill presented on 3 August 1966 per section 16(1) Customs Act.
Appellant filed Writ Petition No. 9 of 1967 under Article 226 before Judicial Commissioner, Goa, Daman and Diu, Panaji; upheld Customs order on 5 April 1968.
Appeal by certificate to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether shipment and export of iron ore by appellant became liable to export duty introduced by notification on 2 August 1966, having regard to provisions of section 16 of Customs Act 1962.

petitioner_arguments.text: Shipping bill presented on 1 August 1966 and entry outwards granted prior to 2 August 1966; notification under section 4-A Indian Tariff Act 1934 not applicable; no duty payable per section 16 Customs Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 16 Customs Act 1962; Section 4-A Indian Tariff Act 1934

respondent_arguments.text: Shipping bill deemed presented on date of vessel arrival (3 August 1966) as presented before entry outwards; liable for duty effective 2 August 1966.

court_reasoning.text: Under section 16(1)(a) Customs Act, rate of duty applicable on date shipping bill presented under section 50; proviso: if presented before entry outwards, deemed presented on date of entry outwards.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Entry outwards granted on 30 July/1 August 1966, prior to 2 August 1966 notification; shipping bill not deemed presented on arrival date.

court_reasoning.text: Sections 50 and 51 deal with entry and clearance for export; endorsements on 1 and 2 August permitted export; goods described as free.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No provision in 1962 Act to deem presentation on vessel arrival date unlike 1878 Act.

court_reasoning.text: Customs authorities acted without jurisdiction by holding date of entry outwards as vessel arrival date.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Order of entry outwards made prior to notification date.

holdings.text: Export not liable to duty introduced on 2 August 1966; appellant entitled to cancellation of notice dated 28 January 1967.

statutes_cited.name: Customs Act, 1962
statutes_cited.relevance: Determines date for rate of duty, entry and clearance of export goods; shipping bill deemed presented on date of entry outwards if prior.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Tariff Act, 1934
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to amend schedule introducing export duty on iron ore effective 2 August 1966.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for writ petition challenging Customs order.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgment of Judicial Commissioner dated 5 April 1968 set aside; writ issued quashing notice dated 28 January 1967 and order of Assistant Collector dated 19 April 1967; respondents restrained from proceeding pursuant to notice.
outcome.relief_granted: Cancellation of demand for export duty Rs. 98044; quashing of notice and order.

key_quotes.text: The rate of duty and tariff valuation, if any, applicable to any export goods, shall be the rate and valuation in force- (a) in the case of goods entered for export under section 50, on the date on which a shipping bill... is presented...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes section 16 Customs Act central to determination of applicable duty date.

key_quotes.text: For the foregoing reasons the appellant is entitled to an order cancelling the notice dated 28 January, 1967...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Concludes in favour of appellant, resolving the controversy.
